metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Function overloading allows multiple functions to have the same name, as long as their parameters are different in type or number :
content.html: Function overloading allows multiple functions to have the same name, as long as their parameters are different in type or number:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myFunction(int x)float myFunction(float x)double 
  myFunction(double x, double y)

content.code:
int myFunction(int x)float myFunction(float x)double
myFunction(double x, double y)

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myFunction(int x)float myFunction(float x)double 
  myFunction(double x, double y)

content.code_html:
int myFunction(int x)
float myFunction(float x)
double myFunction(double x, double y)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myFunction(int x)float myFunction(float x)double 
  myFunction(double x, double y)

content.text: This lets you use the same function name for similar tasks.
content.html: This lets you use the same function name for similar tasks.

content.text: Consider the following example, which have two functions that add numbers of different type:
content.html: Consider the following example, which have two functions that add numbers of different type:

content.code_html:
int plusFuncInt(int x, int y) {
  return x + y;
}

double plusFuncDouble(double x, double y) {
  return x + y;
}

int main() {
  int myNum1 = plusFuncInt(8, 5);
  double myNum2 = plusFuncDouble(4.3, 6.26);

  cout << "Int: " << myNum1 << "\n";
  cout << "Double: " << myNum2;
  return 0;
}

content.text: Problem: We had to create two different function names for the same logic.
content.html: Problem: We had to create two different function names for the same logic.

content.text: Instead of defining two functions that should do the same thing, it is better to overload one.
content.html: Instead of defining two functions that should do the same thing, it is better to overload one.

content.text: In the example below, we overload the plusFunc function to work for both int and double :
content.html: In the example below, we overload the plusFunc function to work for both int and double:

content.code_html:
int plusFunc(int x, int y) {
  return x + y;
}

double plusFunc(double x, double y) {
  return x + y;
}

int main() {
  int myNum1 = plusFunc(8, 5);
  double myNum2 = plusFunc(4.3, 6.26);

  cout << "Int: " << myNum1 << "\n";
  cout << "Double: " << myNum2;
  return 0;
}

content.text: Note: Multiple functions can have the same name as long as the number and/or type of parameters are different.
content.html: Note: Multiple functions can have the same name as long as the number and/or type of parameters are different.

content.text: Function Overloading by Number of Parameters
In this example, we overload a function by using a different number of parameters:
content.html: In this example, we overload a function by using a different number of parameters:

content.code_html:
int plusFunc(int x, int y) {
  return x + y;
}

int plusFunc(int x, int y, int z) {
  return x + y + z;
}

int main() {
  int result1 = plusFunc(3, 7);
  int result2 = plusFunc(1, 2, 3);

  cout << "Sum of 2 numbers: " << result1 << "\n";
  cout << "Sum of 3 numbers: " << result2;
  return 0;
}

What is function overloading in C++?

metadata.question: What is function overloading in C++?

options.text: A function that always returns the same result
Using multiple variables in a single function
A method to automatically generate functions
Creating multiple functions with the same name but different parameters
